channel.title: AO Guide – Celestial Mechanics and Astrodynamics
channel.description: Recent content in Celestial Mechanics and Astrodynamics on AO Guide

item.title: Kepler's Laws
item.description:
Newton’s law of universal gravitation describes gravity as a force by stating that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers of mass. Consider two bodies of masses m1m_1m1​ and m2m_2m2​, with position vectors r1⃗\vec{r_1}r1​​ and r2⃗\vec{r_2}r2​​. The force exerted on body 2 due to body 1 is

F⃗=−Gm1m2r3r⃗ \vec{F} = -\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r^3} \vec{r} F=−r3Gm1​m2​​r

We define the following:

  • Separation vector: r⃗=r2⃗−r1⃗ \vec{r} = \vec{r_2} - \vec{r_1} r=r2​​−r1​​
  • Total mass: M=m1+m2M = m_1 + m_2M=m1​+m2​
  • Reduced mass: mμ=m1m2m1+m2m_\mu = \frac{m_1 m_2}{m_1 + m_2}mμ​=m1​+m2​m1​m2​​
  • Gravitational parameter: μ=GM\mu = GMμ=GM

Here G is the gravitational constant, equal to 6.67430×10−11 m3 kg−1 s−26.67430 \times 10^{-11} \: \mathrm{m^3\,kg^{-1}\,s^{-2}}6.67430×10−11m3kg−1s−2 . Using Newton’s second law F⃗=ma⃗\vec{F} = m \vec{a}F=ma, we can write

r⃗¨=−μr⃗r3 \ddot{\vec{r}} = -\mu \frac{\vec{r}}{r^3} r¨=−μr3r​

Working in the center of mass frame, we have

m1r1⃗+m2r2⃗=0⃗ m_1 \vec{r_1} + m_2 \vec{r_2} = \vec{0} m1​r1​​+m2​r2​​=0

Hence the individual position vectors can be expressed as

r1⃗=−m2Mr⃗ ,r2⃗=m1Mr⃗ \vec{r_1} = \frac{-m_2}{M} \vec{r} \,, \qquad \qquad \vec{r_2} = \frac{m_1}{M} \vec{r} r1​​=M−m2​​r,r2​​=Mm1​​r

The total orbital angular momentum is given by

L⃗=m1r1⃗×v1⃗+m2r2⃗×v2⃗=mμr⃗×v⃗ \begin{align*} \vec{L} &= m_1 \vec{r_1} \times \vec{v_1} + m_2 \vec{r_2} \times \vec{v_2}\\ &= m_\mu \vec{r} \times \vec{v} \end{align*} L​=m1​r1​​×v1​​+m2​r2​​×v2​​=mμ​r×v​

where v⃗=r⃗˙\vec{v} = \dot{\vec{r}}v=r˙. The total energy of the system is given by

E=12m1v12+12m2v22−Gm1m2∣r1⃗−r2⃗∣2=12mμv2−μmμr2 \begin{align*} E &= \frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 + \frac{1}{2} m_2 v_2^2 - \frac{G m_1 m_2}{|\vec{r_1} - \vec{r_2}|^2} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} m_\mu v^2 - \mu \frac{m_\mu}{r^2} \end{align*} E​=21​m1​v12​+21​m2​v22​−∣r1​​−r2​​∣2Gm1​m2​​=21​mμ​v2−μr2mμ​​​

We define the specific angular momentum and specific energy as

h⃗=L⃗mμ=r⃗×r⃗˙ε=Emμ=12v2−μr \begin{align*} \vec{h} &= \frac{\vec{L}}{m_\mu} = \vec{r} \times \dot{\vec{r}}\\ \varepsilon &= \frac{E}{m_\mu} = \frac{1}{2} v^2 - \frac{\mu}{r} \end{align*} hε​=mμ​L​=r×r˙=mμ​E​=21​v2−rμ​​

Since gravitation is a central force, the angular momentum is conserved. Moreover since it is conservative, the total energy is also conserved. Hence h⃗\vec{h}h and ε\varepsilonε are constants of motion.

Since h⃗⋅r⃗=0\vec{h} \cdot \vec{r} = 0h⋅r=0, h⃗\vec{h}h lies perpendicular to the plane of motion, and hence defines the plane of motion. We have

ddt(h⃗×r⃗˙)=h⃗×r⃗¨=(r⃗×r⃗˙)×(−μr⃗r3)=−μ1r3[(r⃗⋅r⃗)r⃗˙−(r⃗⋅r⃗˙)×r⃗]=−μ(r⃗˙r−r⃗r˙r2)=ddt(−μr⃗r) \begin{align*} \frac{d}{dt} (\vec{h} \times \dot{\vec{r}}) = \vec{h} \times \ddot{\vec{r}} &= (\vec{r} \times \dot{\vec{r}}) \times \left( -\mu \frac{\vec{r}}{r^3} \right) \\ &= -\mu \frac{1}{r^3} \left[(\vec{r} \cdot \vec{r}) \dot{\vec{r}} - (\vec{r} \cdot \dot{\vec{r}}) \times \vec{r} \right] \\ &= -\mu (\frac{\dot{\vec{r}}}{r} - \vec{r} \frac{\dot{r}}{r^2}) = \frac{d}{dt} \left(-\mu \frac{\vec{r}}{r} \right) \end{align*} dtd​(h×r˙)=h×r¨​=(r×r˙)×(−μr3r​)=−μr31​[(r⋅r)r˙−(r⋅r˙)×r]=−μ(rr˙​−rr2r˙​)=dtd​(−μrr​)​  ⟹  ddt(h⃗×r⃗˙+μr⃗r)=0⃗ \implies \frac{d}{dt} \left( \vec{h} \times \dot{\vec{r}} + \mu \frac{\vec{r}}{r} \right) = \vec{0} ⟹dtd​(h×r˙+μrr​)=0

Hence we define the eccentricity vector as

e⃗=−h⃗×r⃗˙μ−r⃗r \vec{e} = -\frac{\vec{h} \times \dot{\vec{r}}}{\mu} - \frac{\vec{r}}{r} e=−μh×r˙​−rr​

This is another constant of motion. It lies in the plane of motion, hence h⃗⋅e⃗=0\vec{h} \cdot \vec{e} = 0h⋅e=0. It points in the direction of the periapsis. The mangnitude of the eccentricity vector is equal to the eccentricity of the trajectory.

e=1+2εh2μ2 e = \sqrt{1 + \frac{2 \varepsilon h^2}{\mu^2}} e=1+μ22εh2​​

The angle between the eccentricity vector and the position vector is called the mean anamoly

r⃗⋅e⃗=recos⁡f=r⃗⋅(−h⃗×r⃗˙μ−r⃗r)=h2μ−r \vec{r} \cdot \vec{e} = r e \cos f = \vec{r} \cdot \left( -\frac{\vec{h} \times \dot{\vec{r}}}{\mu} - \frac{\vec{r}}{r} \right) = \frac{h^2}{\mu} - rr⋅e=recosf=r⋅(−μh×r˙​−rr​)=μh2​−r  ⟹  r=h2/μ1+ecos⁡f \implies \boxed{r = \frac{h^2 / \mu}{1 + e \cos f}} ⟹r=1+ecosfh2/μ​​

This, if one may recognize, is the equation of a conic section in polar coordinates, with the focus being at origin, and h2μ\frac{h^2}{\mu}μh2​ is the length of semi latus rectum. The magnitude of e⃗\vec{e}e determines the shape of the trajectory:

  • e=0e = 0e=0: Circle
  • 0≤e<10 \leq e < 10≤e<1: Ellipse
  • e=1e = 1e=1: Parabola
  • e>1e > 1e>1: Hyperbola

where the focus or the conic section lies at the center of mass of the system.

For a bound orbit, the total energy of the system must be negative

ε<0 \varepsilon < 0 ε<0

This gives the eccentricity of the orbit to be between 0 and 1, hence the orbit is an ellipse.

For our solar system, the sun is much more massive than any of the planets, hence is nearly at the center of mass, or the focus of the elliptical orbits of all planets. This proves Kepler’s first law of planetary motion, which states that the orbit of a planet is an ellipse with the sun at one of the foci.

The cross product of two vectors gives the area of a parallelogram possessing sides of those vectors, hence the triangular area dAdAdA swept out in a short period of time is given by half the cross product of the r⃗\vec{r}r and dx⃗\vec{dx}dx vectors, for some short piece of the orbit, dxdxdx.

dA=12∣r⃗×dx⃗∣=12∣r⃗×v⃗dt∣=h2dt dA = \frac{1}{2}|\vec{r} \times \vec{dx}| = \frac{1}{2}|\vec{r} \times \vec{v} dt| = \frac{h}{2} dt dA=21​∣r×dx∣=21​∣r×vdt∣=2h​dt  ⟹  dAdt=h2 \implies \boxed{\frac{dA}{dt} = \frac{h}{2}} ⟹dtdA​=2h​​

which is constant, since h=∣h⃗∣h = |\vec{h}|h=∣h∣ is constant. This proves Kepler’s second law of planetary motion, which states that a line segment joining a planet and the sun sweeps out equal areas during equal intervals of time.

The third law of planetary motion states that the square of the period of revolution of a planet is directly proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit. This can be proved by integrating the equation of areal velocity, using the fact that the area of an ellipse is πab=πa21−e2\pi a b = \pi a^2 \sqrt{1 - e^2}πab=πa21−e2​. For an ellipse, the length of semi latus rectum is b2a=a(1−e2)\frac{b^2}{a} = a (1 - e^2)ab2​=a(1−e2), hence h2=μa(1−e2)h^2 = \mu a (1 - e^2)h2=μa(1−e2). Integrating through one whole revolution,

dA=h2dt∫dA=h2∫dtπa21−e2=12μa(1−e2)T \begin{align*} dA &= \frac{h}{2} dt\\ \int dA &= \frac{h}{2} \int dt\\ \pi a^2 \sqrt{1 - e^2} &= \frac{1}{2} \mu a (1 - e^2) T\\ \end{align*} dA∫dAπa21−e2​​=2h​dt=2h​∫dt=21​μa(1−e2)T​

Rearranging, we get

T2=4π2μa3 \boxed{T^2 = \frac{4 \pi^2}{\mu} a^3} T2=μ4π2​a3​
